$$y'' + p(t)y' + g(t)y = 0$$
Linear ODE in y, with non-constant coefficients

$$L[y] = y'' + p(t)y' + g(t)y$$

Linearity to solve all IVP from 2 solutions

If $y_1, y_2$ are solutions to $L[y]$, they are called a fundamental set if any solution to $L[y]$ can be written a linear combination of $y_1$ and $y_2$

$$y(t) = c_1y_1(t) + c_2y_2(t)$$

To satisfy the IVP, we want
$$\left[\begin{matrix} y_0 \\ y'_0 \end{matrix} \right] = \left[\begin{matrix} y(t_0) \\ y'(t_0) \end{matrix}\right] = c_1 \left[\begin{matrix} y_1(t_0) \\ y'_1(t_0) \end{matrix}\right] + c_2 \left[\begin{matrix} y_2(t_0) \\ y'_2(t_0) \end{matrix}\right] = \left[\begin{matrix} y_1(t_0) & y_2(t_0) \\ y'_1(t_0) & y'_2(t_0) \end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix} c_1 \\ c_2 \end{matrix}\right]$$

If the Wronskian $W$ of the matrix of functions $y_1,y_2$ and their derivatives is not $0$ (i.e., $W \neq 0$) then there is a unique solution $c_1,c_2$ for a given initial value $y_0,y'_0,t_0$. We say the vectors are linearly independent.

If $W=0$, then we manipulate $W$ into two equivalent fractions and see that the slope of the vectors is the same and thus cannot be linearly combined into a solution. They are linearly dependent.

$$y'' + 6y' + 8y = 0$$

Find fundamental solutions
(typically, guess $y = e^{rt}$, giving $r = -2, -4$)
Do these form a fundamental set of solutions (is the Wronskian $0$)?
$W = -4e^{-2t}e^{-4t} - 2e^{-4t}e^{-2t} = -6e^{-6t} \neq 0$

Aside
$$\cosh(t) = \frac{e^t + e^{-t}} 2$$
$$\sinh(t) = \frac{e^t - e^{-t}} 2$$
$$\cosh'(t) = \sinh(t)$$
$$\sinh'(t) = \cosh(t)$$

Doing the linear combination $\frac 1 2 e^{-2t} + \frac 1 2 e{-4t} = \frac 1 2 e^{-3t} (e^t + e^{-t}) = e^{-3t}\cosh(t)$ means this is a solution. We obtain $e^{-3t}\sinh(t)$ by similar methods.
